ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
MALAYSIA-SINGAPORE AIRLINES
(Restructure of)


    1. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Finance whether it was not possible to reconcile the conflicting objectives of the Singapore and Malaysian Governments on the running of MSA, chiefly in relation to the expansion of Malaysian domestic air services, in order to avoid a dissolution of their partnership. Next, what is the current state of the negotiations and what are the objectives of the proposed Singapore national airline.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, it has become common knowledge that the policies and objectives of the Governments of Singapore and Malaysia towards Malaysia-Singapore Airlines have become divergent. Differences have arisen from time to time in recent years.

    On the 2nd September, 1970, the Malaysian Ministry of Foreign Affairs delivered a note to the Singapore High Commission in Kuala Lumpur requesting the Singapore Government to designate a committee of officials to discuss with their committee the creation of a

Column: 976

Malaysian Domestic Airline. On the 13th November, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs delivered a note in reply to the Malaysian High Commission in Singapore nominating this committee.

    The differences of objectives between the two Governments have become irreconcilable. A parting of the ways was unavoidable. Continuation of the partnership would only have led to constant friction and unnecessary conflict.

    The Singapore Government's interest is centred upon a fast-expanding commercially viable operation with flights on international routes to Europe and the United States. The Malaysian Government has different priorities. A major point of disagreement was the proposal to expand MSA domestic air services regardless of the loss forecast by management.

    Now that the decision has been taken to dissolve the co-ownership and joint control of MSA, it is in the best interests of both Governments that the proposed restructuring of the company should be proceeded with as expeditiously as possible. There are good reasons for proceeding with deliberate speed. First, in the airline business nothing stands

Column: 977

still. The transitional period before restructuring is completed is not conducive to the taking of important decisions on the expansion of services and the acquisition of new aircraft. Secondly, staff of the company, contractors, agents, suppliers and clients would find a long transitional period unsettling not knowing where exactly they stand. Thirdly, Government officials as well as the staff of MSA who are directing, planning and undertaking the arrangements for the restructuring of the company cannot have their attention distracted from their normal duties for a prolonged period of uncertainty and restlessness pending the final hiving off into two separate airlines.

    Negotiations between officials of the two Governments have resulted in a measure of agreement. There are a few points on which further talks are to take place. It has been agreed that, first, the restructuring will be completed by the end of 1972 or any earlier date that may be agreed upon by the two Governments; secondly, that the Fokker aircraft will be transferred to the proposed Malaysian national airline and the Boeing 707 aircraft to the Singapore national airline; thirdly, that projects approved will be implemented and that projects required for the orderly growth and expansion of the company will not be held up on account of the proposed restructuring of the airline. The Governments have also appointed, through MSA, a reputable firm of accountants to value the assets, both tangible and intangible, of the company; the report of the accountants is to be submitted by 30th June this year.

    The Singapore Government has proposed that, to facilitate the establishment of the Malaysian national airline, the internal operations of MSA should over a period of time be separated, and placed under the control of a "Malaysian Division" of the company. In the near future, such a Division would become the nucleus of the Malaysian national airline and would be handed over as such. It is the intention of the Singapore Government that this transfer should take place as soon as possible.

Column: 978

It is the Singapore Government's intention that there will be completely separate financial accountability in respect of domestic services under the Malaysian Government, and international services under the Singapore Government, by 1st. January, 1972, or that the national airlines of the two countries should be on their feet by the 1st January, 1972.

    I have dealt with the distribution of the Fokker and the Boeing 707 aircraft, but not with the Boeing 737 aircraft. These aircraft are used extensively on services between Singapore and Malaysia as well as on international routes stretching to Bangkok, Hong Kong, Djakarta, Bali and Sumatra. Clearly, a sharing of these aircraft will have to be worked out on the basis of the requirements and interests of each Government. This basis will be decided at separate negotiations on an air services agreement which are scheduled to be completely by the end of this month.

    It is appropriate for me to outline the policy of the proposed Singapore national airline. We have conveyed to the Malaysian Government the fact that the Singapore Government will inherit the corporate entity of MSA which is; a Singapore registered company, as was its precursor, Malayan Airways.

    There should not be any hiatus in the rapid growth of the airline. Since the bulk of MSA's international services are operated on Singapore traffic rights and as a considerable proportion of traffic originating in the Singapore-Malaysia region is derived from Singapore, the proposed restructuring of the company will not impair its growth prospects. MSA is now preparing a five-year development plan which, subject to scrutiny and approval by the Government, will be implemented vigorously. I understand that consideration of the purchase of wide-bodied aircraft is one of the highlights of the plan.

    Employment opportunities in a wholly- owned Singapore company should grow at a rapid rate. Management will be given a free and unfettered hand to carry out its tasks under the effective control and supervision of the Board of

Column: 979

Directors. With good management and run on the basis of efficiency and profitability, our national airline has considerable growth expectations. It should be at least as profitable as and probably larger than Hong Kong's airline. Unlike Cathay Pacific which is not allowed to cut into BOAC's profitable international routes, we shall circle the globe.

2.41 p.m.

    Head 0801 (contd.) -

    The Chairman: Head 0801 - amendment (18) . The Question is,

    "That the sum to be allocated for Head 0801 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2109."

    The Minister for Education had the Floor when the Committee rose last Friday night,Mr Lim.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think I have clarified all the doubts that were in the minds of Members at the last sitting with regard to this subhead. Unless they want further clarification, I propose that we go on to the next amendment.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Sir, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

Column: 980



    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0801 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2118*.

    (* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr N. Govindasamy.)

    Sir, I notice that there is an increase of $1.1 million for the 1971-72 estimate over the 1970-71 estimate in regard to the item of "Substitute Relief Teachers". I presume that this additional sum of money is for the Ministry of Education to employ more relief teachers in the coming year.

    At present, the ratio between the number of relief teachers and the total number of permanent teachers reaches an unhealthy proportion. Any further increase of the present number of relief teachers is going to further aggravate the situation.

    I would like to ask the Minister whether he should not consider the immediate reintroduction of part-time teacher training at the Teachers' Training College at this stage. I am quite confident that the response to part-time teacher training will be good. Part-time teacher training will alleviate the present shortage of teachers.

    The advantage of part-time teacher training over full-time training for student teachers is that while undergoing training they will be able to earn a salary which will help them economically, whereas in the case of full-time students, not only are they not paid a salary but they also have to pay tuition fees instead.

    We must appreciate the position of many school leavers who do not come from well-to-do homes and who would like to earn a living after the completion of their studies. For such persons, while they may not take on full-time teacher training because they will become economically inactive when undergoing training, they may find it attractive enough to do part-time training and, at the same time, earn a salary as trainee teachers in schools.

    Sir, a partial solution to the problem of teacher shortage is the reintroduction of part-time teacher training.

Column: 981



2.45 p.m.

    Mr N. Govindasamy (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, for the last three years I have been harping on the matter of substitute relief teachers without appearing to make much headway with the Ministry of Education. If I have harped on the subject over and over again, it is because, having been long with education and having children in school who are sometimes taught by these substitute relief teachers, I sincerely believe that it is about time that the Ministry of Education gradually stopped its existing practice of using unqualified youngsters as relief teachers and made attempts to replace them with a corps of qualified teachers. It appears that the number of unqualified relief teachers increases year after year with no sign of any attempts being made by the Ministry of Education to rectify this, to say the least, unhappy education system. The provision for substitute relief teachers for 1969-70 was $1.2 million for 15 months. The provision for 1970-71 was $1.3 million. This year, as the Member for Moulmein has pointed out, the provision is $2.4 million. Can the Minister tell the House what attempts the Ministry has made to rectify this unhappy practice?

    Sir, amongst the ranks of the relief teachers there are many who would want to make teaching their career, but they are not given the opportunity or the training to become qualified teachers. Why cannot the best of these relief teachers who wish to make teaching their career be given part-time teacher training, as has been advocated by the Member for Moulmein, so that they will take up teaching as a career and not as a stepping stone to other jobs? What we must not forget is that the backbone of our teaching profession today comprises teachers who have had part-time teacher training. There are many who become daily-rated teachers today while waiting for some other employment. In any case, this business of unqualified relief teachers teaching in our schools is a bad reflection on our education policy and at the same time makes a mockery of teaching as a profession.

Column: 982



    Sir, to hear the Minister advance the practice of leave-taking among teachers as a reason for the need of relief teachers, it would appear that teachers have never taken leave previously. This is, of course, not true. Teachers have gone on leave before. It is not a recent phenomenon, as was pointed out earlier. But what really happened in those good old days, not more than four or five years ago, was that there were one or two extra qualified teachers in every school to take over classes from the regular teachers who went on leave. But now with the quota of teachers rigidly imposed on every school, there is the problem of relief teachers who are unqualified to take over classes from the qualified teachers. As a result, we have been relying on unqualified persons to act as relief teachers. Sir, if there is a shortage of qualified teachers - and I believe there is - as a result of some planning defect in the Ministry of Education, some serious attempts must be made quickly and effectively to obviate the need of using unqualified people as relief teachers in schools. One way is to increase the output of trained teachers. The reason for regular class teachers to be trained is equally applicable to temporary relief teachers. The minds of the future citizens of Singapore are too precious an asset to be imperilled by improper teaching.

    Sir, the Minister has mentioned that the response to advertisements in respect of recruitment of teachers was poor. Did the Ministry attempt to find out the reason for the lack of response from our school-leavers waiting for jobs? I can advance my own reason, but I will be accused of harping on salaries and working conditions all the time. Let the Ministry of Education advance their reasons for the lack of response from qualified persons for not wanting to become teachers. Perhaps one of the reasons advanced by the Member for Moulmein may stand up. Is it because teachers in training have to pay for their training and, as a result, they are not responding?

Column: 983



    Sir, you will notice that this year the vote asked for in the General Education Department alone is almost twice as much as that for last year. Of course, the allocation will have to be more if we include the vocational institutes and technical schools in this particular vote. If the Ministry of Education does not make any serious attempts to remedy the situation, I am sure that next year this vote of $2,400,000 that we are asked to approve this year will have to be doubled. When this sorry state of affairs is going to end will be a big question mark. Sir, not very long ago we were talking in terms of coming to the end of the phase of quantitative education and launching on to qualitative education. May I humbly suggest that we have not even arrived at this phase at all. A total of 99 per cent of our schools are still functioning as two-session schools. The number of classes in schools has not been reduced; the number of pupils per class has not been reduced; and the shortage of teachers has increased year after year. When can we have qualitative education at this rate? Sir, all persons who are interested in education and who have children in school would want their children and future citizens to be taught by persons who are teachers by training and by choice, and not by persons who act as relief teachers for $7 or $8 a day, or whatever the daily wage that the Ministry of Education pays them. So long as this phenomenon of substitute relief teachers exists in our schools, we will have to remind the Minister that it has got to stop. Can the Minister for Education inform the House of any plans that the Ministry may have to overcome this educational problem that we face?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, fortunately enough I have looked into the establishment of my Ministry, otherwise after listening to the two Members I would have thought that my Ministry had been staffed completely by relief teachers! Actually, only five per cent of them are relief teachers, and

Column: 984

the other 95 per cent consist of a hard core of fully competent teachers who are there by their own choice. I would like very much indeed to see all one hundred per cent of the establishment filled by people who become teachers "by their own choice", to quote the words of the Member for Telok Blangah. It is because we do not have enough people who want to join the teaching service by their own choice that we are at present in this plight, and have to resort to engaging five per cent of the staff as relief teachers. The key words here are "by their own choice".

    Let me take the point raised by the Member for Moulmein. I am very glad indeed that, whether consciously or unconsciously, he has advocated the point which I have made about not proceeding with the setting up of the Institute of Education. It is precisely because of the fear that I had of having insufficient people enrolling to pay for an education in order to be able to teach four years later that I have had second thoughts, and he has stated it correctly in this House that there are lots of people who would prefer to learn while they work. The question of whether we should institute full-time training for these relief teachers is under consideration by my Ministry, because what started on an ad hoc basis looks as if it is going to become a permanent feature in the Ministry of Education, largely because - and I repeat - there are insufficient people who would opt to teach. Therefore, we are seriously considering the proposition whether we should reintroduce part-time training. But here again, may I point out to the House the problem of sufficient staff to teach these relief teachers who will be going in for part-time training. This is a question of staff and facilities. In the same ways we would very much prefer, if we could, to have one-session schools in Singapore right through. We are prevented from doing that largely because of the insufficient facilities for one-session schools. It means that we have almost physically to double the school buildings that we have now. For the information

Column: 985

of Members, when I attended the Commonwealth Education Ministers' Conference recently in Australia, I was surprised to find that a large number of countries were very much interested in our two-session schools because, to their minds, this feature represents the full utilisation of the resources at one's disposal. So while we here may think that it is an unsatisfactory way to cram all our students in the schools, others think it is one way of fully utilising one's resources. It could be that the double-session school is a way out for most countries. Maybe later on we will reach a state of affluence and, with reclamation making good progress and providing us with sufficient land, we may be able to build single-session schools for all children going to school.

    The Members for Telok Blangah and Moulmein are wondering why there is an increase in the vote for relief teachers. As I have said, what has started on an ad hoc basis is probably becoming permanent, but I can tell them that my Ministry now is doing its very best to relieve the situation. All I can promise is that things may get a little bit worse before they get better, largely because of the difficulties involved. It takes about three years at least to train a teacher. If we start making teaching as a career more attractive or enlarging the intake of trainees in the Teacher's Training College, you will not see the result until three years after.

3.00 p.m.

    As for the measures taken by the Ministry to solve the problem of shortage of staff, I have figures here to show that the intake of the T.T.C. has been greatly increased. We expect 660 trainees to qualify this year and 950 next year. Thus the intake is increasing. Therefore, you can see that relief is on the way, and I hope the Member for Telok Blangah need not stand up again and say that he has been at this problem for the last five years.

    As regards the increase in the workload, I believe this is due to the fact that we are also engaging graduates as

Column: 986

relief teachers. Unfortunately, there is a certain quota to be observed with regard to the intake of graduates and T.T.C.-trained teachers. This may be due to financial considerations but it is largely because the professionals have advised that we should maintain a certain proportion. In their view, it would not be realistic at this stage of our development to have the full complement staffed with graduate teachers. If Members want to know all the facts, they can refer to the professionals in the Ministry of Education, who are their colleagues or ex-colleagues. Anyway, I completely disagree with the Member for Telok Blangah when he said that we have not succeeded in expanding quantitatively.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Point of clarification, Sir.

    The Chairman: Mr Lim, are you prepared to give way?

    Mr Lim Kim San resumed his seat.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Sir, what I said was that since we have finished with the quantitative phase, we should now talk in terms of the qualitative phase of education. My question was: when can we achieve qualitative education? Not quantitative education.

    The Minister of State for Education (Dr Lee Chiaw Meng): Not overnight.

    Mr Lim Kim San: We are in the process of trying to achieve that, but there are many matters to look into now. I think the Member is not unaware that there has been a curriculum revision in the Ministry. There is a Department of Research looking into ways and means of improving methods of teaching. We have launched the Educational T.V. service, and we are using all forms of aids to reach the young minds. And improving the quality of education is not an overnight process. It takes a long time and careful research. I would say that our circumstances here are different from those in most other countries, because when we set out to achieve multilingualism, or at least bilingualism in the schools for the

Column: 987

majority of our students, it was not just a question of learning two languages but three. We must remember that our students have also to learn the native tongue used in their homes.

    The Chairman: Mr Lim, your ten minutes are up.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, I think I have dealt with almost all the points raised, but if Members have any more queries, they can raise them under some other amendment so that I will try to answer them.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I wish to inform the Minister that consciously or unconsciously I am not advocating the abolition of the Institute of Education, because I do not see the point there. The Institute of Education does not necessarily have to confine itself to full-time teacher training, as after all there are other activities to think of. And even if there is a reason to hold back full-time teacher training and part-time teacher training, it does not mean that we must also hold back the establishment of the Institute, because, as I have said, the Institute of Education could incorporate so many other forms of activity. Anyway, the Minister has said that next year over 600 trainees will pass out from the T.T.C. and the following year another 900 trainees will qualify. The question I want to ask is this: will all these teachers be given jobs? It must be remembered that much money has been spent on the training of these teachers. It has happened in the past that teacher-trainees who underwent training and obtained the Certificate of Education were not guaranteed jobs, and I have pointed this out in this House previously. This is one of the disincentives to this full-time teacher training, and therefore there is no response because, apart from the fact that they do not earn any salary while undergoing training, there is no guarantee that they are going to get jobs at the end of the course. So you can see the kind of

Column: 988

situation that the teacher training scheme is in when there is this disincentive in the system. Therefore, I just want to ask the Minister whether he can give the assurance that all these teachers will be given jobs when they pass out from the T.T.C.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, I am not aware of any teaching institution in the world guaranteeing jobs for its graduates. And I am afraid I cannot start a precedent. If the Minister for Finance, my colleague here, would like to guarantee them jobs, then that is his business.

    Mr N. Govindasamy: Sir, I think the Minister did not answer my question, which is this: will the Ministry look into the possibility of again instituting part-time teacher training in order to overcome the present shortage of teachers?

    Mr Lim Kim San: I think I did answer that question, and I said that the matter is under consideration. But while it is being considered, I would like to ask Members to appreciate the problem of getting sufficient teaching staff to teach these trainees. I have mentioned this in the course of my reply earlier.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong: Sir, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0801 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 3001.

    Sir, at this stage of our educational development, when the emphasis is on qualitative rather than quantitative education, I am surprised to note that the ensuing year's allocation for the item "Educational Exhibitions, Career Conventions and Teachers' Seminar" has suffered a cut of $3,500 as compared with the allocation for the previous year. The amount allocated for the previous year was $10,500, but this has

Column: 989

been reduced to $7,000 for 1971-72. Activities under this subhead are to me of tremendous educational value, and I should imagine that the vote should be increased rather than decreased, if we are really serious about pursuing qualitative education.

    With reference to the "Teachers' Seminar", I would like to draw the attention of Members to the recent Teachers' Seminar from 27th February to 1st March, 1971, organised by the Singapore Teachers' Union. Some 250 teachers participated, together with representatives from the Ministry of Education and the Teachers' Training College. The seminar papers, as well as the discussions, were guided by a sense of proportional responsibility and realism on the part of the participants.

    It is important that the seminar papers, as well as the findings of the seminar on various professional problems of the teachers, should be discussed among teachers in the schools. The Singapore Teachers' Union, therefore, intends to organise group meetings of teachers on Saturdays to enable as many teachers as possible from the various schools to benefit from the ideas contained in the seminar papers as well as the conclusions of the seminar. I would like to ask the Education Minister if he thinks that it will be a good idea for the Singapore Teachers' Union, the Education Ministry Research Unit, the Inspectorate of the Education Ministry and the Teachers' Training College jointly to organise meetings of teachers to enable them to discuss their professional problems with a view to establishing a larger sense of involvement and participation in the educational development of Singapore. I am also sure the Minister will agree with me that if Inspectors of Schools are asked to hold seminars or group meetings of teachers to discuss the educational and professional problems of teachers, this would be a much more fruitful way for them to spend their time than going around snooping and investigating complaints from anonymous letters.

Column: 990



    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Mr Speaker, Sir, if I may briefly make a few points. I would like to support what the Member for Moulmein has said, and perhaps articulate specifically the point he has raised - that there should be more of these seminars. In my own experience, I find them to be very useful, but perhaps more use could be found at district level. In other words, the organisation of these educational seminars, which at present is confined only to the central level, should be brought lower down to the district level, so that a number of schools could come together and join in these discussions, and maintain a continuing discussion of their role in relation to society.

    The other point I would like to make is this. Perhaps the Ministry of Education could give teachers a feedback as to what it thinks of the proposals that have been formulated at these seminars. This will encourage teachers to express their views continually on the sort of action which the Minister himself has sought to encourage.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Sir, the Member for Moulmein is out of date. Inspectors do not snoop around inquiring into fictitious complaints. I have already made it clear to them that unfortunately their office carries some sort of an odium about it; and that their job is not so much inspection of schools as advising and helping teachers and principals of schools to achieve the quality of education that we want and to carry out the policy that we have set out to achieve.

    As regards the Teachers' Seminar, which was organised recently by the Singapore Teachers' Union, of course. I was very much encouraged by the response given to it, and by the discussions that took place. I very much welcome the suggestion of the Member for Moulmein to get the various sectors of the Ministry of Education to enter into a dialogue on the role of education and on education itself in Singapore.

Column: 991



    What has made it necessary for me to stand up here to reply is because of the confusion that has arisen with regard to the reduction of the vote. Actually there is no reduction in the allocation for "Education Exhibitions, Career Conventions and Teachers' Seminar". What happened was that out of the provision of $10,500 for the financial year which is about to end, there was included a sum of $5,000 for guidance and placement. But this sum has now been transferred to the vote for the Technical Education Department. Therefore, though the sum asked for is $7,000, there is, in fact, an increase of $1,500 in the provision. We feel that this vote should be enough for the use of "Educational Exhibitions, Career Conventions and Teachers' Seminar". But should there be a shortage, I can assure Members that during the course of the financial year if seminars are held and proved to be of practical value - I have no doubt at all that they will be of value if enough thought and interest are shown by those who participate -we will either ask for a supplementary vote or vire the amount from savings, if any, from other heads of expenditure.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,
